author: mini_mads1980
title: Good Set At A Good Price
review:
I just got my Arctic Ice Crawler from one of the two big toy shops at Bristol's Cribbs Causeway.  This was the only one of the Arctic sets that they had, so I was not able to take too much advantage of the 10% off for the Bank Holiday weekend.

As soon as I saw these sets I knew I wanted them, so hopefully once made they will be as good as I hoped.

Box/Instructions

The box has a large image on the front of the Ice Crawler with the sole occupant holding a pick-axe, with the ice rock hanging from the arm of the Ice Crawler. On top of the box there is the 1:1 scale image of the Minifig, placed at a right angle to normal due to the size of the box.  Also on top of the box is an image of the Minifig holding a saw this time, having opened the ice rock revealing the precious material inside.

The box has various warning messages on the bottom and the barcode.  The side you open has the same image as the front, and the other side has information regarding where the bricks were made and a logo for the Lego Club.

Inside the box there is a 48-page instruction book, a sticker sheet, two un-numbered bags and two rubber wheel tracks.  The booklet does give nice images of the other Arctic sets and the new train sets.

Minifigures

You only get one Minifig in this set, so I would say other sets are more desirable.  The vehicle can't contain more than one Minifig, so there are no complaints from me regarding the number in the set.

The build

The build could not be classed as tricky at all.  My only real complaint would be step 29, where you place the grey 4 bar to the top of the windscreen.  As the roof of the cab is not connected to the back of the cab, I pushed the bar into place and took the whole thing off!

The completed model

The completed model is not anything special, but by no means bad and took a little over ten minutes to build.  It seems sturdy enough and is not likely to fall apart too easily, despite the cab connection at the back, when in play.  The Minifig sits nicely in the middle, however I always prefer to change the construction to have the driver on the right, I am English after all!

Overall opinion

I like this set, but I think 60035 will be my favourite from this theme.  Also, the £10 (ish) price tag for this set with one Minifig is fair.

author: CrescentSky
title: To The North Pole!
review:
When I bought this set, I had no idea of how good it would turn out. For a relatively cheap price, this set comes with the truck, an ice block, one minifig, and much more.

Box/Instructions

The box is unusually long for city sets, and is probably too big for the size of the set, but overall not a big deal. The instructions are classic city instructions, easy to follow and read.

Parts

Nothing too fancy here, though it's worth mentioning that there are two 1x2 cheese slopes in orange, and an orange 1x6x4 wall piece. The rest of the set has pretty common pieces.

Minifigures

One minifig is included in the set, an explorer with a heavy jacket and parka. The torso,legs, and hood are the same ones in all other arctic sets, and the head is in some other sets as well. It is detailed well, however, and works fine for the set.

The build

The build is nothing special, but enjoyable nonetheless. I was actually surprised by how much I liked building it, even though it only took me abut five to ten minutes. A child would be fine building it by themselves though. Generally just a nice, standard city build.

The completed model

The completed model looks good for what it is and functions nicely. The treads work great on all surfaces (because they're rubber), and the crane on the back has good mobility. The only thing I would point out is that it appears a bit stubby and short lengthwise.

Overall opinion

I grew to like this set before I bought it, and now that I have I love it. I was able to get it for $12.74 USD, but even at $14.99 USD retail it's still a good price. If you want an arctic set, I would definitely recommend this one.
